questions.text: The pupil that responds to convergence but with an absent light reflex is known as a?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Argyll Robertson pupil Argyll Robertson pupil (ARP) . Here both pupils are slightly small, and a reaction to near reflex is present. Still, light reflex (both direct and consensual) is absent, i.e., there is light near dissociation (to remember, the acronym ARP may stand for ‘ accommodation reflex present’). Both pupils are involved and dilate poorly with mydriatics .

Highyeild:

It is caused by a lesion (usually neurosyphilis) in the region of the tectum.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Adie's pupil Option: C. Hutchinson pupil Option: D. Myotonic pupil TONIC PUPIL Damage to ciliary ganglion or short ciliary nerves causes tonic pupil Anisocoria-affected pupil is larger Absent light reflex/vermiform contraction Very slow near reflex. Accommodative paresis The pupil constricts with 0.125% pilocarpine(cholinergic supersensitivity) Causes-viral infection, orbital trauma, diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A third-year neurology resident found that a light reflex was absent in the right eye and the absence of a consensual reflex in the normal eye in a patient who had come to OPD. This reflex is called?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Amaurotic Light Reflex Amaurotic light reflex. It refers to the absence of direct light reflex on the affected side (say, right eye) and the lack of consensual light reflex on the normal side (i.e., left eye). This indicates lesions of the optic nerve or retina on the affected side (i .e., right eye), leading to complete blindness. In diffuse illumination, both pupils are of equal size.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Wernicke's hemianopic pupil. It indicates a lesion of the optic tract. In this condition, the light reflex (ipsilateral direct and contralateral consensual) is absent when light is thrown on the temporal half of the retina of the affected side and the nasal half of the opposite side. In contrast, it is present when the light is thrown on the nasal half of the affected side and the temporal half of the opposite side. Option: C. Marcus Gunn pupil. It is the paradoxical response of a pupil to light in the presence of a relative afferent pathway defect (RAPD) Option: D. Adie’s tonic pupil

questions.text: Shivamma, a 30 years old lady, came to OPD. A third-year ophthalmology resident found that reaction to light is absent and to near reflex is very slow and tonic. The cause is due to a lesion in the?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Postganglionic Parasympathetic Damage Adie's tonic pupil - In this condition, reaction to light is absent, and to near reflex is very slow and tonic. The affected pupil is larger ( anisocoria ). It is caused by postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage . It is usually unilateral , associated with an absent knee jerk and occurs more often in young women.

Highyeild:

Adie's pupil constricts with weak pilocarpine (0.125%) drops , while the normal pupil does not because the denervated iris sphincter is super sensitive to topical parasympathomimetics .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Preganglionic parasympathetic damage - not the correct option. Option: C. Postganglionic sympathetic damage - not the correct option. Option: D. Preganglionic sympathetic damage - not the correct option.

questions.text: Which of the following does not constitute part of the pupillary light reflex? a) Pretectal nuclei b) Superior colliculi c) Inferior colliculi d) Edinger Westphal nucleu e) Short ciliary nerves f) Lateral geniculate body Select the correct answer from the given below code:

options.label: B
options.text: Only c and f are correct.

options.label: C
options.text: Only a,b, and c are correct.

options.label: D
options.text: Only a,b,c, and d are correct.

questions.correct_answer: B. Only c and f are correct.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Only c and f are correct. The lateral geniculate body and inferior colliculi is not a part of the pupillary reflex pathway. It is part of the accommodation reflex and the visual pathway. Pupillary light reflex pathway: First, neurons (sensory) connect each retina with both pretectal nuclei in the midbrain at the level of the superior colliculi. Second neurons (internuncial) connect each pretectal nucleus to both Edinger Westphal nuclei. Third neurons (preganglionic motor) connect the Edinger-Westphal nucleus to the ciliary ganglion. Fourth neurons (postganglionic motor) leave the ciliary ganglion and pass in the short ciliary nerves to innervate the sphincter pupillae.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. both C and F are correct statement Option: C. both C and F are correct statement Option: D. both C and F are correct statement

questions.text: A NEURO OPHTHALMOLOGY intern on his ICU duty found that on pinching skin over the side of the neck of the patient in a comatose patient, there is rapid dilation of the ipsilateral pupil. Which of the following forms an afferent limb of the reflex associated with dilation of the pupil?

options.label: D
options.text: Trigeminal nerve or cervical pain fibres.

questions.correct_answer: D. Trigeminal nerve or cervical pain fibres.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trigeminal nerve or cervical pain fibres. Afferent inputs of this reflex are carried by the trigeminal nerve or cervical pain fibres (lateral spinothalamic tract). It synapses at the ciliospinal centre of Budge, located at C8 to T2 in the intermediolateral (IML) horn of the grey matter of the spinal cord.

Highyeild:

The efferent branch of the reflex consists of the following:

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: A and B.Preganglionic sympathetic fibres from the upper thoracic and lower cervical spinal cord, which go to the cervical sympathetic chain and its three ganglia. Options: C and D. The postganglionic sympathetic fibres pass on the surface of the internal carotid artery and join the ophthalmic nerve at the cavernous sinus. Here, it passes through the nasociliary nerve to reach the ciliary body and innervates the dilator pupillae muscles, causing dilatation of the pupil.

questions.text: The test shown is done to detect which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Marcus Gunn pupil Marcus Gunn, pupil. It is the paradoxical response of a pupil to light in the presence of a relative afferent pathway defect (RAPD) . Causes of Marcus Gunn's pupil include incomplete optic nerve lesions and severe retinal diseases. A swinging flashlight test tests it.

Highyeild:

Marcus Gunn's pupil is the earliest indication of optic nerve disease, even in the presence of normal visual acuity in the affected eyes.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Amaurotic light reflex - Option: B. Wernicke's hemianopic pupil- Option: D. Adie's tonic pupil-

questions.text: Seema, a 29 years old lady, was neurologically examined. It was found that on shining light in his left eye, the left pupil doesn’t constrict, but the right pupil does. On shining light in his right eye, the right pupil constricts, and the left doesn’t. The defect is in the following:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left eye efferent Light reflex : When light is shone in one eye, both the pupils constrict . Constriction of the pupil to which light is shone is called direct light reflex, and that of the other pupil is called consensual (indirect) light reflex . Light reflex is initiated by rods and cones . Pathway of light reflex include

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Afferent fibres extend from the retina to the pretectal nucleus in the midbrain. These travel along the optic nerve to the optic chiasma, where fibres from the nasal retina decussate and travel along the opposite optic tract to terminate in the contralateral pretectal nucleus . At the same time, the fibres from the temporal retina remain uncrossed and travel along the optic tract of the same side to terminate in the ipsilateral pretectal nucleus. Option: B. Internuncial fibres connect each pretectal nucleus with Edinger-Westphal nuclei of both sides. This connection forms the basis of the consensual light reflex. Option: D. Efferent pathway consists of the parasympathetic fibres, which arise from the Edinger-Westphal nucleus in the midbrain and travel along the third (oculomotor) cranial nerve. The preganglionic fibres enter the inferior division of the third nerve and, via the nerve to the inferior oblique, reach the ciliary ganglion to relay. Post-ganglionic fibres travel along the short ciliary nerves to innervate the sphincter pupillae.

questions.text: A 78-year-old right-handed man with hypertension and hyperlipidemia was brought to the emergency department for sudden onset of nausea and vertigo 1 hour ago. Physical examination shows 5/5 strength in all extremities. Sensation to light touch and pinprick is decreased in the right arm and leg. A brain CT scan shows an acute infarction in the distribution of the left posterior cerebral artery. Further evaluation of this patient will likely show which of the following findings?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Right-sided homonymous hemianopia The posterior cerebral artery supplies the occipital lobe. The posterior cerebral artery supplies parts of the thalamus and the visual cortex within the occipital lobe. In addition to contralateral hemisensory loss due to lateral thalamic infarction (as seen in this patient), occlusion to the posterior cerebral artery causes damage to the visual cortex, resulting in contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing.

Highyeild:

Central vision is not impaired in posterior cerebral artery infarction since the middle cerebral artery supplies the corresponding cortical area of the macula.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Right upper homonymous quadrantanopia would suggest a lesion in the left optic radiation and can be seen in strokes involving the left middle cerebral artery. This finding would not be expected in a posterior cerebral artery stroke patient. Option: B. Prosopagnosia is most commonly seen with right posterior cerebral artery strokes (e.g., infarction of the right occipitotemporal lobe). This would not be an expected finding in a patient with a left posterior cerebral artery stroke, as seen here. Option: D. Left-sided hemineglec t would be consistent with damage to the right parietal lobe (e.g., due to a right middle cerebral artery stroke), which is usually associated with contralateral motor and sensory deficits.

Extraedge:

A posterior cerebral artery stroke was diagnosed, in this patient, and no motor deficits are present.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a sudden, painless loss of vision in her right eye that occurred 30 minutes ago while watching TV. She has coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus and has had trouble adhering to her medication regimen. Her blood pressure is 160/85 mm Hg. Examination shows 20/50 vision in the left eye and no light perception in the right eye. Direct pupillary reflex is present in the left eye but absent in the right eye. Accommodation is intact bilaterally. Intraocular pressure is 16 mm Hg in the left eye and 18 mm Hg in the right eye. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows a pale, white retina with a bright red area within the macula. The optic disc appears normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Central retinal artery occlusion Indirect pupillary reflex will likely be absent in the left (not right!) eye, which would be consistent with retinal or optic nerve damage.< The patient has multiple risk factors for retinal artery disease, including diabetes, hypertension, and atherosclerosis. Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) is characterised by sudden, painless loss of vision and an afferent pupillary defect.

Highyeild:

Ophthalmoscopy findings of CRAO include retinal pallor and a cherry-red spot in the foveal region. Narrow retinal vessels with a cattle-truck appearance are another classic finding of retinal artery occlusion.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Hypertension, diabetes, and atherosclerosis are all risk factors for ischemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) . It may present with sudden, painless loss of vision, a relative afferent pupillary defect,, and severe edema of the macula and optic disc. However, fundoscopy would reveal focal retinal hemorrhage instead of a white, pale retina. The most common form of CRVO is nonischemic and results in a decrease in visual acuity over a few days instead of a sudden loss of vision seen here. Option: B. Both hypertension and diabetes mellitus are risk factors for retinal detachment. Patients with extensive retinal or retinal detachment involving the macula would also present with sudden, painless loss of vision and an afferent pupillary defect. However, fundoscopy would reveal a gray, detached, freely floating gray retina . Retinal pallor and a cherry red spot within the macula suggest a different diagnosis. Option: D. Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy may also present with sudden, painless vision loss. However, fundoscopy would reveal a hyperemic or edematous optic disc and possibly splinter hemorrhages within the optic disc, unlike a normal optic disc seen in this patient.

Extraedge:

Retinal and macular changes would also not be present. Retinal pallor and a cherry red spot within the macula suggest a different diagnosis.
